Reviews.Content: Functional This is what I could call a big and boxy, ordinary Japanese urban hotel -- catering to the Japanese traveling middle class, some foreigners and, especially it seems, flight crews. My very expensive room was not ready until mid-afternoon on check-in on New Year's Day. This was irritating after flying in from South Asia. But I understood that the place had been fully booked for New Year's Eve. The rooms are modern with good amenities supplied. There is in -room high-speed broadband, which is free.The hotel is an easy walk to Shinagawa station.My only major complaint was that when I ordered an ala carte breakfast I got cold eggs but they were replaced quickly with profuse apologies. I don't know that I would stay here again, however, unless there were absolutely no other choices in this category (which is how I ended up here in the first place).
Reviews.Author: 7J1AIL

Reviews.Content: Heated in Chilly Tokyo!       Reception counter
Reviews.Author: crispypata

Reviews.Content: Dated hotel but close to Shinagawa station We stayed at this hotel 4 nights of our Japan tour. The rooms are quite dated and small but clean. The breakfast room is very beautiful with the fountain, waterfalls and koi pond which surround it on three sides. However, the breakfast buffet is quite ordinary.The hotel is located right across the street from the Shinagawa station which makes it quite convenient.
Reviews.Author: Capucine7

Reviews.Content: Good business hotel, great transport connections       Shinagawa station crossing
Reviews.Author: svalbard_view

Reviews.Content: Great Central Location I selected this hotel for a one night stay to allow some sightseeing around Tokyo before catching a flight out of Narita. The location is extremely convenient to the station and worked as a good central spot to go around town. By subway, nothing was more than 190 Yen (about 15 Min) away, and making the connection to the N鈥橢X was very easy. The station isn鈥檛 too bad to navigate through either.Onto the room. I stayed on the Pacific Level floors and in a double room and it was very tastefully redone in a modern style. Everything was new, and even included full personal kits for two people with high line products and a CD/ DVD player  LCD TV. Although not huge, (It鈥檚 Japan, remember) the bathroom was very large  had everything in it. After being in hotels all week with 鈥淢odule Bathrooms鈥? it was a very nice break. I鈥檇 put it level with the better Westin  Marriott remodels found in the US. Spend the extra to get this room type, it鈥檚 worth it.The hotel is older but appears that they are updating areas quietly, as I didn鈥檛 see any construction but there were signs of new items around the place. The gardens are very nice. Also, if you are extremely homesick for mass produced US food, they have a TGI Fridays as part of the hotel. But there are many better options directly across the street in the plaza attached to the Sony building. Service I found to be great and the breakfast buffet was quite large, at 2350 Yen it did give all the items you would expect at that price. At breakfast, I left behind a guidebook in the restaurant and went up to my room. Before I got there, they had already taken the book to the front desk  called my room to let me know I forgot it. And they were very accommodating about a late check out request. The hotel does cater to international travelers, so language was not an issue, especially at the front desk.
Reviews.Author: MFRoadWarrior

Reviews.Content: Great Location. Hotel's location is just across street from Shinagawa Station.       Bathroom
Reviews.Author: beagle1984

Reviews.Content: Convenient for station but a little jaded I did use my Starwood points to stay here so only paid $45 a night but was pretty disappointed by the aged look of the hotel.It really does need an overall as very much stuck in the 80's and not at all what i am used to at Le Meridien's! The room we had was so small there was hardly room for our bags and the bathrooms were pretty old fashioned too.However this place is convenient for stations to central Tokyo as across the road from Shinawaga station which is on the central ring and minutes from Tokyo central.
Reviews.Author: Charleyquant

Reviews.Content: Good business hotel       View on Tokyo Tower (room view)
Reviews.Author: Travelguy0

Reviews.Content: Negative experience An Hotel that should be closed for an appropiate refreshment and a courtesy training to the staff.Room was old and the the mattress was terribly hard. Around 9 pm we have required to change the mattress but the last solution founded by the only one kind staff in the hotel has been to put some towel on it. A terrible night. The day after we have cancelled our reservation and transferred in another hotel.
Reviews.Author: diabro

Reviews.Content: Not bad for a business hotel! I stayed at Le Meridien Pacific for three nights in September, 2007. I found the accommodations to be more than adequate, but not the same as Western hotel accommodations at all! I'm not sure what rate my company paid for the rooms, but I know they weren't cheap. The room contained two beds; I'm guessing twin size or something pretty close. They were nothing like the cushy beds we've come to expect in American hotels. Very hard and not particularly comfortable. The room was very clean. The shower in the bathroom was wonderful; great water pressure. (although it took me a few minutes to figure out how it was supposed to work!!) As in most offices, restaurants, and hotels that I experienced in Japan, the toilet was a bidet. Most interesting in contrast to the Japanese-style toilets that are basically just troughs in the ground! If you visit Japan, be sure to look for the signs that point towards the western toilets!There was a fairly well-stocked mini bar in the room, although I didn't use anything except the coffee (included water, beer, wine, liquors, snacks). No coffee maker in the room; however, there was a ceramic stove eye of sorts that you could use to heat water. There was a sort of drip package of coffee available on the mini bar which cost approximately $3 US.(made one cup). Not too bad if you need caffeine before you face the world!I had a very nice view out of my window, especially at night.I'm not sure if the hotel offers bell service ; it wasn't offered to our group but it may be because the company told them we'd take care of ourselveslThe breakfast buffet offered more than you could possibly want. There were many Japanese offerings as well as traditional Western foods. There was a salad bar; Japanese rice porridge; Miso soup; and a few other Japanese items. There was also an omelet station where a chef would prepare your omelet to order(fascinating to watch him with a small saute pan and only two chopsticks as cooking utensils; made an absolutely beautiful omelet!) There were also several fruit selections, several types of cereal; bacon, ham, scrambled eggs, fried eggs, boiled eggs, and a great assortment of pastries (NOT cheap doughnuts; there were croissants, chocolate croissants, and an apple pastry made from croissant dough that was to die for!) You could also make toast if you wished; and I believe pancakes were offered at least one of the mornings I was there. Again; not sure of the cost, as my company paid for it, but it was extremely good.If I were traveling to Tokyo, I would probably check out all the options as far as cost; but there wouldn't be any reason not to recommend this hotel if the cost was reasonable.
Reviews.Author: JMRN

Reviews.Content: Only an OK Shinagwa hotel If you have business in Shinagawa area, this hotel is perfectly located next to the station and the Takanawa shopping and restaurant wings. That's probably the best thing about it, with exception of perhaps rather lovely garden and man-made waterfalls one overlooks from the buffet breakfast room.Hotel is dated, service (for Japan) is somewhat average, not too clean, not too anything. Cups not cleaned away from previous day, supplements not replaced. Breakfast is also very average, but you get vouchers, and that's better than having to wonder around looking for something in the morning, or relaying on its average room service menu. There is no fitness room.Add to that the fact that there was absolutely no internet connection on the 21st floor I stayed in, it's not a flash proposition for a business stay. The so-called 'business lounge, consisting of 5 chairs randomly assembed in the lobby where people with no business as such hang out or loiter and is useless. From previous experience few months back, The Prince hotel next door is not much of an improvement unless you stay in a business room in the New Tower, but it's still better than Le Meridien Pacific.
Reviews.Author: la10_travel

Reviews.Content: Average Hotel with Poor services I stayed at this hotel during September 3-5, 2007. I was very disappointed when I walked into the room. The room was quite small. The bathroom is a small module. It does not look like a Le Meridien hotel room. The TV set was very old.I picked the hotel for its location near Shinagawa station. The only good thing about the hotel is its location. I was also very disappointed at the breakfast. At a cost of 2,425 Yen, there's not much choice of the foods. The concierge was not very helpful. Due to an incoming typhoon, I was trying to leave one day earlier. The concierge was unable to help me changing the reservations. I had to go to Narita airport to change my reservations.The hotel gives two bottles of water for the first night only. Any additional bottle will be a room charge.My overall experience with the hotel was terrible.
Reviews.Author: Worldadvisor

Reviews.Content: Basic hotel in Tokyo, a bit removed from the action This was my first time staying at this hotel in this part of Tokyo since my favorite Imperial Hotel was full. I was on a business trip and didn't need luxury accommodations. The Meridien was a basic business hotel as others have mentioned. The breakfast buffet was probably the biggest disappointment for me. It was very limited with mainly American-style selections such as scrambled eggs, bacon, pastries, juices and cereal. I got tired of it after a couple of mornings. I was hoping to have more Asian foods in the buffet. The room was fine, comfortable bed and nice room decor. The bathroom was motel-like with a standard tub-shower and tiny surface area to put bathroom things like toothpaste or a shaver. I was also unhappy to see that in order to get onto the Tokyo subway, I either had to take a JR train to a subway stop or to walk a bit to a subway station. Note however that the staff were very professional and the facility was spotless. I just like a hotel with a bit more differentiation. Would I stay at this hotel again? Sure, if I needed to.
Reviews.Author: pauloregon

Reviews.Content: meridien I use to stay at this hotel in tokyo, it s a good place nice and polite staff, but always the same breakfast....tight rooms and mobile home style bathroom but good location near the shinagawa station, bounded to major locations in tokyo and the jr line .no fitness club but swimming pool open during the summer.
Reviews.Author: sarakawi

Reviews.Content: Comfortabe        bedroom
Reviews.Author: Travelgypsyisme

Reviews.Content: average, like a 3+star by western standards in transit for another business trip, we were put in this large smoked filled lobby hotel. once again the lobby does not represent the hotel rooms. once on the floors, you will be able to tell its outdated-ness. we had a double room. it was nice and clean, just small and dated. internet was free which was the best part. bathroom was TINY for us 'large' americans (and i wouldnt even consider us overweight). only english channel was BBC, fine for a one-night stay. TGIF was attached to the hotel. the shinagawa train station is right across the street. didnt really get to explore the area, but it looked like there were a lot of shopping and restaurants close by. wasnt too impressed with the hotel overall. staff were friendly tho.
Reviews.Author: centrum

Reviews.Content: Good basic hotel but with tiny bathrooms! Stayed here for 3 nights on recent business trip. Although the hotel is efficient in typical Japanese style, the bathrooms are absolutely minute! I also found the staff in the breakfast area less than helpfull,not least of all due to poor English skills. On the positive side the hotel is conveniently close to Shinagawa station.
Reviews.Author: Comfy-Traveller

Reviews.Content: Convenient location. But that is about it. Stayed in this hotel regularly on business, and these are the points I found noteworthy:Good:- Convenient location across Shinagawa station will get you anywhere in Tokyo metropolitan area within 30 minutes.- Has a limousine bus arriving  leaving for Narita right in front of the door.- Rooms have free high-speed internet- Convenience store downstairs open until 00:30.- A 25$ cab will take you home from Shibuya/Roppongi, etc.Bad:- Very shabby and old, used-up interior. No investment done for 20 years.- Very old-fashioned and stiff service staff.- Minimal adjustments (on  off) for the heater- Very shabby, all-plastic bathroom with flair of capsule hotel- CNN is the only non-Japanese channel on the 20 year old TV- The breakfast is definitely not worth the 2500 yen. avoid at all costs.- The restaurants are old and shabby. - No good restaurants/bars nearby. Remote from the real Tokyo.- Staff not as friendly as usual in JapanConclusion:If you are on business, and you only need a place to sleep, and you are getting a good rate, why not. But if you intend to spend more time than 10 minutes each morning and night, and they do not give you the 15.000 yen/night rate, try to spend your money elsewhere. The hotel is soulless and worn out, filled with cheap tour groups and grey business men.
Reviews.Author: kotarok

Reviews.Content: sketchy and not so cozy This was our first time in Tokyo for our honeymoon and this hotel was everything we did not ask for or want for our stay. While it was across the street from Shinagawa station, there was not much around the hotel except for office buildings. As such, the nightlife and commercial area we were seeking was nonexistent and about a $50 cab ride away. What was concerning to us was that the hotel had the feel of a cheap motel 6, with bad decor, bad service, and shady atmosphere. The furniture seemed dated back to the 70's and we received no invoice or receipt when we decided to check out to find a different hotel altogether. We did not want to spend one night here. Perhaps if you're a businessman wanting to take advantage of the in-room massage service, this might be for you.
Reviews.Author: traveling_couple2006

Reviews.Content: Great Location
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Great deal, good location, fabulous concierge! I stayed at the Le Meridien Pacific in Jan 05 as part of a go-today.com package. Excellent value! Was a short walk to the JR Yamanote line. Was not expecting Park Hyatt levels of luxury (given the price); so I think it was a fantastic value. The concierge, in particular, was exceptional. A previous review noted that the concierge is not available in the evenings. However, our group did not find this to be constricting. Every morning the concierge helped us book meal reservations, and provided maps (in English!) to all the sites we were planning to visit. The small bakery on the lower level was also great for an early morning snack. Very fresh baked goods.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Convenient Location My tour group stayed at this hotel for 3 nights. The staff were very helpful and courteous (most japanese people are). The hotel was located across the street from the shinagawa train station and just a few stops from shibuya. There were many eating places around the hotel. The room was a standard japanese room. It was quiet and clean with a desk, table and chairs. There were free toiletries, a hot plate, free tea, a refridgerator, and a hairdryer. The restaurant had a breakfast and dinner buffet which was okay. There was a free shutlle to and from the Daiba LeMeridien Hotel and was one of the stops for the airport transport bus.
Reviews.Author: jaw40

Reviews.Content: Good experience The room was somewhat small by American standards, however very clean well appointed and very efficient staff. Had to settle for two single beds, however, we did make a last minute reservation. Would go each day for help on how to get places( first time to Tokyo) and received nothing but the most helpful advice, maps, directions etc. from staff. The location of the hotel is very good right across the street from Shinagawa station and close to many restaurants and shopping including a grocery store. All and all a good experience.
Reviews.Author: gnomehome

Reviews.Content: Excellent accomodations, service, and value I enjoyed my stay, the accomodations were excellent, the rooms were very clean, yet slightly small, not an issue. The ajoining resturante (Piccolo Mondo) service was prompt, and exceeded my expectations, the food was good, diverse menu choices. Overall it was a good lodging experience, the location is exceptional, very close to Shinagawa station.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Yuk! This is a very big hotel with absolutely no soul or character. The rooms are shabby. It also did not feel very welcoming to western tourists. The service was sufficient in most cases but there was supposed to be a concierge but apparently he goes home before 7pm. Not very helpful for figuring out where to go for dinner! We decided to check out after one night and switch hotels. I guess we expected much more from a Le Meridien property. In fairness, it is ok if you keep very low expectations.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
